It may be used freely by individuals for research, teaching, and personal use as long as this statement of availability is included in the text. bibl.title: [Letter] ca. 1831, [to] William / James Moore King
bibl.author: King, James Moore
bibl.note: This is a letter written ca. 1831, presumably from James Moore King; the recipient is only identified by William. The letter consists of adulation, and highly descriptive language of audience reactions to colts and stallions at an exhibition in Murfreesboro.

projectDesc.p: Created for the University of Tennessee Digital Library

editorialDecl.p: Quotation marks retained as data except inside q tags
Errors in transcription of the printed text controlled with X-Metal 3.0 spell-checker; text has also been thoroughly proofread.
Corrections and normalization represented by editorial tags.
Catchwords and directional notes such as "turn page over" have been omitted.

refsDecl.p: ID attributes provided for only those pages, chapters, or illustrations toward which a reference or figure points.

div1.p:
With pleasure I acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 19th Feby which was gratifying to hear from you and my friends, but with feeling of simpathy I regreted to see the statement of the death of your infant son., J.K In your former letter you spok of an excurtion you had taken for the examination of some gold mines I should like to hear what the prospects are. (the winter has been remarcable sevear, but I am inhopes it is now broke, as we have had seviral weeak of butiful weather,) I have been informed by Coln Hing that he has brought your two maires with him, to either go to Richard or Champion, I informed him that I should be much gratified in their going to sir Richard and if he would send them I would take them in charge and use my best endeavou to have them got in fold by Sir Richard, If there be any other person you stated that if your accquaintance that wishes to send you may assure them that all care wil be set and with measure your Linolian coalt died, It was truly a loss indead for I believed it ⁁ was an un common fine coalt; your Richard coalt mare state come's on finely, which I am inhopes he it will be able to distinguiss him itself superior to any nag that ⁁it he may have to contend with; and should be gratified to see him it on the Harrican Hill Turf making some of thois efforts of distinction, and your preasants to witness it: I am inhopes, I do not anticipate your presence invain at some of our amusement on the Harrican Hill Turf — who W.R. or Has. Devane King?
to comply with your invite, at Tuskaloosa next fall, but it is quite out of — my power to do so, as I am prepairing to build, I have some fine coaltes and I think promising and do expect to train one or 2 this fall. I cannot forbear giving you a short detail sketch of the exhibition of fine stallions a feiw weeaks a go at Murfreesboro; — Among there ware the Jefferson by Virginian, Sir Charles Pinkney by Old Sir Charles, De Foe by conquerer, Traveller by A Jackson. I and Sir Richard, besides several others —there was a large crowd of — spectators to view those fine loaded animals as their war several that had beengreatly much talked about, and had never been shone there before The spectators formed a circle in which the horse entered, among them Dick mooved in with magnificent splendor, his butiful arched neck aloft in the air exyes sparkling with excitement, his long and silver glossed tail twirled on his back and with gallant strides moved with exquisite grandure round and throug the admired spectators it was a unanimous tone among the numerous crowd, that he was the finest and the most splended horse they ever saw, that he was the fare paragon of —animals.

Our friends about N.V. are generally well. also Blackman & family Mother is in very good health, so is Walter & Jane, miself Mark and children are in very good health, tell cousin Ann Washington Lafayette is very fine child, & Jane Helen is two sweeat, and no end to her chattering I sent to you a few day a go a newes paper and hand bell
